this is Suzy Menkes in Paris with Alber
Elbaz from Laura Albert Abbas is one of
the few designers who's really marked
the history of fashion in the 20th
century mostly because he thinks about
women first and dressing them second I
think there is a very interesting time
for men because it's almost I could say
it's a bit of a confusing moment for
women but on one hand I feel that women
want to have colors but they were in
black they want to have short but they
are wearing long they wanted masculine
clothes but they're looking for
fragility and feminine pieces so it's
quite difficult to put the point of the
what do women want and I do ask women
what do you want and you know what they
tell me Suzy I want a dress with two
sleeves I did a lot of stretches this
this season almost the whole collection
is about stretch and it's about Jersey
it's about new stretch and it's about
natural stretch and then it was all
about molding and then you kind of
caress the body you hug the body so me I
always said an interesting way of
dressing is when you see a woman with a
dress and not a dress with a woman women
are getting into a city that is very
linear but they are also very fragile
more than ever so I have two very pure
and I have they're very very maximalist
one next to each other and I think that
the fact that we can offer different
things this is what I define not on
today so it's not about in one point of
view and in one story because women are
too strong today they can make up their
mind then we decide what to wear when
how we can just offer and be there
he's had quite a long career starting
with Geoffrey Beene in the United States
and then working with Yamaha in Paris so
he's got a very strong background of cut
and shape always behind everything he
does is this approach that women should
come first
he's certainly paid off at Nova the
house which was more or less moribund
when he took over has now become one of
the strongest and most sought-after
collections in Paris you know I think
the luckiest man in the world on that
term I work with two of my biggest
biggest mentor I mean with Geoffrey
Beene before he passed away I called in
he was in the hospital and I told you
mr. Beene I have to tell you one thing
and I'm going to be really corny once
again and I said what is it out there
and he could hardly talk and I said I
think that everything I know is you you
taught me everything and what he taught
me more than anything that fashion is
not a sketch it's not a fraud in the
back but it's what's in between and then
after seven and a half years I moved to
Paris and then I was introduced to mr.
Sandow and there was another beautiful
experience because what I saw there is
the electricity that clothes can bring
to life I hope that you know one day in
many years when I'll be gone I mean I
seasons that we work with our bear and
